abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Markets Assistance Project
            for Uganda aimed to improve the safety, soundness and
            performance of the Uganda financial system. This was in turn
            aimed at supporting broad-based private sector growth. The
            objective was to be accomplished by: (i) strengthening the
            regulation, supervision and operations of deposit-taking
            institutions; including the resolution and work-out of
            problem banks; (ii) restructuring and privatization of
            Uganda Commercial Bank (UCB); (iii) improving monetary
            management and payment systems; and (iv) developing
            insurance and contractual savings institutions, as well as
            their oversight. The project never became effective because
            two conditions of effectiveness were not fulfilled by the
            Government, namely: (i) the approval of the credit by the
            Uganda Parliament; and (ii) provision of a legal opinion
            from the Attorney General confirming the validity of the
            Development Credit Agreement (DCA). Despite strong
            commitment to implement financial sector reforms by the
            Ministry of Finance and Bank of Uganda, Parliament was
            skeptical about the Government's plans to borrow money
            for the second round of privatization of UCB as the initial
            privatization to Westmont Land Asia in 1997 had proved
            unsuccessful and a great cost to the country.

5081618.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Markets Assistance Project
            aims to improve the safety, soundness, and performance of
            the financial system in Uganda. There are four major
            components. The first strengthens the regulation,
            supervision, and operations of deposit-taking institutions
            by financing consultant contracts; providing specialized
            training of bank examiners; supporting the purchase of
            laptop computers, software, and other equipment; and
            supporting the upgrade of a national bank. The second
            component restructures and privatizes the Uganda Commercial
            Bank Limited by funding a management contract and other
            services as well as funding severance payments for redundant
            staff. The third component improves monetary management and
            payment systems. The fourth component develops insurance and
            contractual savings reforms and regulations by supporting
            the drafting of legislation, financing equipment and
            training, developing pension systems, and assisting capital
            markets development. Other components include finance
            project implementation and an as-needed reserve fund.
